Then there is the psychological shock of losing a carrier (or even having one damaged and put out of action for days / weeks / months). Losing the flag ship / capital ship is a psychological shock that many Navies never come back from. Hence,Â Trafalgar, or the HSF Paralysis after Jutland, IJN post-Midway, or losing Repulse and Prince of Wales.
In each of these cases, the psychological shock was just as important as the immediate victory. Â
If UK lost one of its carriers during the Falklands, the campaign would have ground to a halt --- and the invasion called Off.
In ancient times, it is as if the King was killed at the battlefield --- the army just melts away even though their fighting ability was hardly changed shortly before or after the King was killed.
